item.title: RejectJS 2013 Berlin: welcome our new ES5 overlords
item.content:encoded:
I recently spoke at RejectJS conference in Berlin. 

While we constantly pay attention to new utility libraries, MVC frameworks, and other well-publicised tools, most of our non-library coding hasn’t changed since ES3.

We’re missing out: beyond the obvious, there’s a world of interesting stuff you can and should be doing with ES5: safe extension of inbuilt methods, mechanisms for live binding data and DOM, and a whole host of techniques to make your code shorter and more readable. Best of all, it’s already built into your browser and node.

Video and slides are below.

item.title: Converting your JS presentation deck to PDF
item.content:encoded:
Update Sep 4 2013: if you use bespoke, the changes mentioned in this article have now been merged into bespoke generator. If you use another JS slide deck, please keep reading.

Despite hacking JS all day I've generally avoided HTML5/JS presentation decks, concerned that I'd spend more time working on the presentation software rather than my deck. 

 After seeing a bespoke.js presentation, liking the rendering performance of the transitions, and being assured it was 'gremlin free' I tried it out:

  • The bespoke grunt generator ensured I was working out of the box with a demo presentation, with my changes being updated live in my browser.
  •  The formatting of the demo slides was clear and simple

After adding my already-prepared content, and spending some time styling, the entire presentation was created in the time I'd allocated to make a decision about what software to use. I can now thoroughly recommend bespoke.js.

Now to throw it onto SpeakerDeck with my other presentations - I love grunt, but I don't want to have someone have to run a server to see my slide deck.

0 page huh? Looks like I have some work to do.

What not to do

I wasted some time with Chrome screenshotting tools, with the aim of making a hacky, image-based PDF. These tools:

  • Cropped parts of the screen when fetching the 'whole screen'
  • Had color correction problems.
  • Would have resulted in a PDF where text wasn't selectable, and my users couldn't paste code into their JS console.

Don't do this.

How to turn any HTML/JS slide deck into a static PDF 

So here's how to do it:

Configuring Chrome Dev Tools for Print Styles

While you work, you'll want to be previewing the document as it would be printed.  See screenshot: 

This will only last as long as you have dev tools turned on.

The obvious stuff - flattening your presentation

Your complete deck will need to be visible in print mode - as a big column of slides. This is a simple mater of adding @print styles to your deck to ensure the next slide is always fully opaque, overflow is visible, etc.

Remove margins around slides too if you want full bleed printing.

This depends on modifying your existing slide deck styles, and is basic stuff that I won't bore you with.

Ensuring slides print in landscape

This will make Chrome's print dialog use landscape by default:

On the top level of your styling:

@page
  size: landscape

That was stylus, BTW, I'll assume you can convert to less/sass/CSS etc.  

Ensure exactly one slide per printed page

After some testing, I found the following value seems to correspond with an A4, landscape page height in Chrome.

 

slide_height_print = 743px

Then on the class for individual slides:

@media print
  height: slide_height_print

Adding page breaks after each slide

Also on the class for individual slides:

@media print
  page-break-before: always

And for the sake of it, add a border-bottom. You know how.

The results

Entire presentation prints, exactly one slide per page, landscape, every page there. 

Print to PDF and you're done. 

Thanks for reading. If you're coming to Berlin in the next couple of weeks for JSconf EU & RejectJS, say hi.

item.title: Free as in time
item.content:encoded:
I once read tech sites absorbing every possible bit of information I could in every spare moment I had. If there wasn’t time to read an article, I bookmarked it for some time in the future when I’d have time to learn the seemingly-important technology.

The bookmarks, as you can imagine, built up fairly quickly. There’s been some discussion recently of declaring ‘inbox bankruptcy’: realising you have no way of having all the time needed to process all the messages waiting and decide to get rid of the old items without reading them.

I find myself needing to declare bookmark bankruptcy.

As I get older I find myself needing to declare bookmark bankruptcy: a point at the time invested in learning new technologies is no longer worth the benefit they may provide (and I stress may - sometimes things don’t work how you expect, are unstable, are badly documented, or won’t have anyone else using it in two years time). Learning stuff takes time. Investment in new tools takes away from immediate returns elsewhere.

I still love technology though, and I still think we can do most things better than we are now. So I’ve got a new technique: start making smaller investments. Half an hour max - that’s almost nothing.

Not just free of cost, but free of time.

This has worked surprisingly well - good technologies - even complicated ones - shine through quickly. I’d like to report that the following things are free − not just free of cost, but free of time. They worked how I expected, and I think you’ll have a similar experience if you try them.

Less CSS

Or sass.css. It doesn’t matter. Both allow you to pick up your existing CSS and use it. No reworking anything. When you want mixins, variables, etc, they’re there and easy to use.

Require JS

I’ve spent more effort reading online discussion and watching conference talks about AMD, common.js, requirejs, and JS modules than it took to actually just decide to use require.js and start using it.

Wrap your existing code in a two-line ‘define’ to specify its dependencies and return anything you’d like to expose to other modules. Then ‘require’ them: from a single script tag in the browser or a ‘require’ statement in node. You now have sweet, async modular loading for complex apps, with the correct order worked out automatically and neat errors when something goes wrong.

Better yet, on Node, require wraps npm, so you don’t have to reinstall anything, you can also load stuff from files - like, say, your public folder. You now have instant code sharing between the server and the browser - go delete some copypasta.

Breakpoint debugging in Chrome

My background’s in Python, and breakpoint debugging isn’t quite as neat there †. JS is a different story: open Dev Tools, click the line. Hover to see variables evaluated to their current version. Hit play to resume. It just works.

Any other tools that you consider ‘free as intime’? Remember: half an hour to pick up, immediate benefit, no refactoring.

item.title: Content creation apps finally get out of the way
item.content:encoded:
When Microsoft Office 4.3 debuted in 1994, the app had what would become a very well known user interface: a row of icons, in colors to match the 20 'reserved' Windows colors along the top of the screen †. The save button was Windows 'dark blue', the new document icon was 'yellow' and 'dark yellow'. These icons lasted 9 years without significant change - Office 97 removed the borders around each icon for a cleaner look, but otherwise everything remained intact.

Office 2003 began departing from the Office look of the last decade, taking advantage of all those new colors modern-day computers provided. Blue gradients were everywhere. The floppy disk 'save' icon became a strange silky soft thing that, if you're old enough to remember floppy disks, you may have trouble recalling. The magnifying glass has a wooden handle, the printer looked like a tiny picture of a printer complete with a little green light on it to show you it was printing. Office 2003 looked immediately distinct from both previous versions of Microsoft Office and OpenOffice.

Office 2007 continued the trend:

Office 2007 seems to have forgotten its purpose: actually making documents.

Oh dear. Office 2007 was unpopular for other reasons - users didn't like the tabbed toolbars - but there's something else going on here: Office 2007 seems to have forgotten its purpose: actually making documents. The user interface has started to become worthy of attention in itself.

Microsoft seem to have noticed this: Office 2010 reigned in the Office 2007 design:

Office 2010 is a mature and subtle iteration of the Office 2007 design. It shifts the focus away from the toolbar and back to the document.

And so we arrive at Office 15:

Using an app to make something isn't about the app, it's about making something.

After nearly two decades, the lesson has been learnt: using an app to make something isn't about the app, it's about making something. Other professional creation creations tools have understood this for years: script writers have Final Draft, programmers have Vim - tools with UIs that are either minimal or hidden completely until the user needs them.

The recent resurgence away from UI chrome started a few years ago: nearly all web browsers removed the multitude of toolbar buttons they'd been accumulating, leaving just the back, forward and reload buttons. Later, iPad Apps like Flipboard: used intuitive gestures rather to replace explicit on-screen navigation. But now there's an industry-wide shift towards content, away from 'featured' user interfaces: Google Docs and GMail have also ditched color icons, and Microsoft's Visual Studio has gotten rid of them:
